The occurrence of DVT complicated or not by PE is based on Virchow's triad: venous stasis, damage to the venous wall and "hypercoagulability".

Venous stasis, for example, is encouraged by surgery, immobilisation, etc.

Endothelial damage is promoted by acute medical events such as sepsis.

Hypercoagulability is promoted by :

- the [[2C-226-ET-A01|acquired thrombophilias or constitutional hereditary thrombophilias]].

- [[Know the situations that favour VTE (circumstances of onset, temporary and persistent favouring factors)|thrombogenic situations such as cancer, inflammatory diseases, pregnancy, post partum....]]

question.title: What promotes hypercoagulability in the context of Venous Thromboembolism (VTE)?

option_a.title: Surgery and immobilization
option_a.description: Venous stasis is promoted by surgery and immobilization, but what else?

option_b.title: Acquired thrombophilias and constitutional hereditary thrombophilias
option_b.description: These are correct, but what else promotes hypercoagulability?

option_c.title: Cancer and inflammatory diseases
option_c.description: These are examples of thrombogenic situations, but are they the only factors that promote hypercoagulability?

option_d.title: Pregnancy and postpartum
option_d.description: These are examples of thrombogenic situations, but are they the only factors that promote hypercoagulability?
